description: From curb (“raised border or frame”) [from mid-17th c.]. Doublet of curve.

entries.meaning: (Britain, Australia, New Zealand) The raised edge between the pavement and the roadway, typically made of concrete though originally consisting of a line of kerbstones.
A stone ring built to enclose and sometimes revet the cairn or barrow built over a chamber tomb.
Alternative form of curb (“raised margin along the edge of a well, etc.”)

verbs.description: kerb (third-person singular simple present kerbs, present participle kerbing, simple past and past participle kerbed)

entries.meaning: (Britain, transitive) To damage vehicle wheels or tyres by running into or over a pavement kerb.
To take a dog to the kerb for the purpose of evacuating.
